1.text: Wilt thou draw out the leviathan with the hook, and press down his tongue with a cord?

2.text: Wilt thou put a rush-rope into his nose, and pierce his jaw with a spike?

3.text: Will he make many supplications unto thee? or will he speak softly unto thee?

4.text: Will he make a covenant with thee? wilt thou take him as a bondman for ever?

5.text: Wilt thou play with him as with a bird, and wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?

6.text: Shall partners make traffic of him, will they divide him among merchants?

7.text: Wilt thou fill his skin with darts, and his head with fish-spears?

8.text: Lay thy hand upon him; remember the battle,â€”do no more!

9.text: Lo, hope as to him is belied: is not one cast down even at the sight of him?

10.text: None is so bold as to stir him up; and who is he that will stand before me?

11.text: Who hath first given to me, that I should repay [him]? [Whatsoever is] under the whole heaven is mine.

12.text: I will not be silent as to his parts, the story of his power, and the beauty of his structure.

13.text: Who can uncover the surface of his garment? who can come within his double jaws?

14.text: Who can open the doors of his face? Round about his teeth is terror.

15.text: The rows of his shields are a pride, shut up together [as with] a close seal.

16.text: One is so near to another that no air can come between them;

17.text: They are joined each to its fellow; they stick together, and cannot be sundered.

18.text: His sneezings flash light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.

19.text: Out of his mouth go forth flames; sparks of fire leap out:

20.text: Out of his nostrils goeth smoke, as out of a boiling pot and cauldron.

21.text: His breath kindleth coals, and a flame goeth out of his mouth.

22.text: In his neck lodgeth strength, and terror danceth before him.

23.text: The flakes of his flesh are joined together: they are fused upon him, they cannot be moved.

24.text: His heart is firm as a stone, yea, firm as the nether [millstone].

25.text: When he raiseth himself up, the mighty are afraid: they are beside themselves with consternation.

26.text: If any reach him with a sword, it cannot hold; neither spear, nor dart, nor harpoon.

27.text: He esteemeth iron as straw, bronze as rotten wood.

28.text: The arrow will not make him flee; slingstones are turned with him into stubble.

29.text: Clubs are counted as stubble; he laugheth at the shaking of a javelin.

30.text: His under parts are sharp potsherds: he spreadeth a threshing-sledge upon the mire.

31.text: He maketh the deep to boil like a pot; he maketh the sea like a pot of ointment;

32.text: He maketh the path to shine after him: one would think the deep to be hoary.

33.text: Upon earth there is not his like, who is made without fear.

34.text: He beholdeth all high things; he is king over all the proud beasts.
